unnormalised: Okay, so you know how everyone's talking about staying fit and healthy these days? Well, let's talk about the OG of health – the heart! As a doc, I see a lot of folks ignoring early signs, thinking "it won't happen to me." But trust me, prevention is way better than cure, especially when it comes to your ticker.
normalised: Okay, so you know how everyone is talking about staying fit and healthy these days? Well, let us talk about the O-G of health – the heart! As a doc, I see a lot of folks ignoring early signs, thinking "it won't happen to me." But trust me, prevention is way better than cure, especially when it comes to your ticker.

unnormalised: First off, let's bust some myths. A lot of people believe heart problems are only for older folks. Nah, even younger peeps are getting hit these days, thanks to stress, junk food, and not enough exercise. Plus, family history plays a big role. If your parents or grandparents had heart issues, your risk is higher. Get checked, especially if you're hitting 30. A simple ECG at, say, Apollo Hospitals or a lipid profile can give you a heads-up.

A simple E-C-G at, say, Apollo Hospitals or a lipid profile can give you a heads-up.

unnormalised: Now, about symptoms. Don't brush off chest pain as "just gas." If you feel a squeezing or tightness in your chest, especially during exercise or stress, get it checked ASAP. Shortness of breath, palpitations (feeling like your heart is racing or skipping beats), and swelling in your legs are also red flags. My colleague, Dr. Sharma, always says, "Better safe than sorry!" He once diagnosed a young guy with a serious condition just because he listened carefully to his symptoms.

My colleague, Doctor Sharma, always says, "Better safe than sorry!" He once diagnosed a young guy with a serious condition just because he listened carefully to his symptoms.

unnormalised: Let's talk numbers. Blood pressure should ideally be around 120/80 mmHg. Cholesterol? Keep that LDL (the bad cholesterol) low, like under 100 mg/dL. And blood sugar? Aim for a HbA1c of around 6.5%. Getting these numbers checked regularly is key to keeping your heart happy. Most labs offer packages that check all these at once, often for around Rs. 1500.
normalised: Let us talk numbers. Blood pressure should ideally be around one hundred and twenty divided by eighty M-M H-g. Cholesterol? Keep that L-D-L (the bad cholesterol) low, like under one hundred M-G divided by D-L. And blood sugar? Aim for a H-b-A-one-c of around six point five percent. Getting these numbers checked regularly is key to keeping your heart happy. Most labs offer packages that check all these at once, often for around rupee one thousand five hundred.

unnormalised: So, what can you do? First, ditch the junk food and embrace a balanced diet. Think lots of fruits, veggies, and whole grains. Cut down on oily stuff and sweets. Regular exercise is a must. Aim for at least 30 minutes of moderate-intensity activity most days of the week. Walking, jogging, cycling – whatever you enjoy! Even simple things like taking the stairs instead of the lift or walking to the market can make a difference.

Even simple things like taking the stairs instead of the lift or walking to the market can make a difference.

unnormalised: Stress management is also super important. Stress can wreak havoc on your heart. Find healthy ways to cope, like yoga, meditation, or spending time with loved ones. Listen to some chill Bollywood tunes! Talk to a therapist if you're struggling to manage stress on your own.

unnormalised: Regarding specific cardiac conditions, things like hypertension (high BP), coronary artery disease (CAD), and arrhythmia (irregular heartbeats) are pretty common. Early diagnosis and treatment can make a huge difference in managing these conditions. Often initial treatment begins with medication, sometimes followed by procedures like angioplasty if blockages are severe (e.g. 90% blockage in a major artery).

Early diagnosis and treatment can make a huge difference in managing these conditions. Often initial treatment begins with medication, sometimes followed by procedures like angioplasty if blockages are severe (for example ninety percent blockage in a major artery).

unnormalised: Finally, don't self-medicate! If you're experiencing any heart-related symptoms, see a doc. They'll be able to properly diagnose your condition and recommend the best course of treatment. Your heart is too precious to take chances with! Remember, you have only 1 heart so take good care of it. Book an appointment with your cardiologist and go for a full body checkup by 12/31/2024 if you haven't done so in the last 1 year.
